div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,477] ALEXANDRIA, Thursday, April 26, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
For the convenience of families and others berths can be definitely engaged at one.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HASELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suskin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddag continuing every other week to Suskin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London, Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The General Administration of the Wakfs informe the public that it possesses at Alex­andrie lands of a superficies of about 18 feddans situated on the bank of the El Farkha Canal, which fetohed at the last adjudication the prioe of L.E 24,500.

The Superior Board of the Wakfs Adminis­tration having ordered the sale by auction of the said lands by way of exchange, the Admi­nistration will reçoive effare on Sunday, 29th April, 1906, from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m., at the offices of the Wakfs Administration, Bab-el-Louk, Cairo, for the renewal of the auction above-mentioned.

Ail persons wishing to take part in this adjudication may see the list of bids at the offices of the administration and make an offer, which must be acoompanied by 20% of the total amuunt in ratio to the above price.

THURSDAY, April 26, 1906.

The "Matin'' States that an Anglo-Franco- Italian convention is negooiating with référencé to the Abyssinien railways: Great Britain and Italy have agreed to the railway between Djibouti and Adis Abeba being managed by Franœ : Great Britain is to hâve the right of oon tin oing the railway beyond Adis Abeba, and renommes the idea of a railway front Barbera inland ; Italy asks for spécial privi­lèges on both railways -. the integrity and indépendance of Abyssinie will be unaffected.(Reuter

div.head:
The Natal Troubles
Assistance from Transvaal

div.p: Sixty per cent, of the Transvaal volunteers have offered themselves for service, the Natal Government has accepted the offer and selected 500 men, who start on Friday.
At a meeting held in Johannesburg it wasresolved to raise a further contingent of five hundred, independently of the Government.
(Reuter)
The Transvaal's assistance is keenly appreciated in Natal.
The Natal Government has wamed the réserves in certain districts, consistiog of ail able-bodied men between eighteen and fifty.
(Reuter)

div.head:
San Francisco Disaster.
Insurance Company's Losses.

div.p: The Royal Insurance Co. States that its possible liabilities in San Francisco amount to £1,850.000: the London aad Lancashire Insurance Company bas been obliged to dépista its réserves by £1,000,000 and has decided to mise £ 600,000 of new capital : the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company estimates its loss as under £ 1,000,000. (B.)

Restoration of the city is proceeding space: the telephone and electric light are being restored: a committee of citizens has been formed with the object of rebuilding one of the most beautiful cities in the world. (Havas)

div.head:
Increases of British Garrison
Profound Impression in Stamboul.

div.p: The news of the increase of the British Army in Egypt has caused a profound impression here.(Reuter)

Count Guioniardini, the Italian Foreign Minister, speaking in the Senate, said that the foreign policy of Italy consisted in fidelity to the Triple Alliance, traditional intimacy with Britain, and sincere friendship with Franoe.
(Reuter)

A conference of employers and the committees of the operative spinners was held yesterday evening : the former agreed to recommend the federation to grant a 5 % advance for a yearfrom the 25th of May on the understanding that an earnest endeavour would be msda to arrange the automatic schem : further negotiations to the same end are to be opened with the cardroom workers. (Reuter)
House of Commons.—The Trades Dispute Bill was read for the second time. (Reuter)
The King and Queen of England have left for Olympia amidst the acclamations of the people. (Havas)
M. Pasitch has formed the new Cabinet.(Havas)

div.head: Fatal Landslip.
div.p: Yesterday, while excavating at Rond Point, Alexandria. a native labourer was overwhelmed in a landslip and suffocated.

div.head: Cairo Mixed Court.
div.p: A new wing is to be built on to the Cairo Mixed Court building at a cost of L.E. 2,500. It is destined for the accommodation of the mort­gage officers.
The Legislative Council.
Owing to the absence of some of the mem­bers, the meeting of the Legislative Council which was to have been held yesterday, was adjourned till Saturday next.
Land Bid.
It is stated that some financial group in Cairo recently offered to purchase the estates of Princess Amineh Hanem, situated at Boulac El Dakrour, at the rate of L. E. 5,000 per feddan.
The Abbassi Mosque.
The Abbassi Mosque, which was recently built by the Wakfs Administration in Sharia El Zaher, Cairo, will be opened to-morrow by the Khedive, who will attend Friday prayers there.
The New Quay.

The S.S. Dartmoor, which arrived here yesterday with a cargo of coals consigned to Messrs. Pharaon Geahel & Co., is the first steamer to moor at the new quay. She will be discharged by Mr. Albert Mussa.
The Late Sayed El Saddat

A memorial service will be held to-morrow evening at the Mirghani Mosque, Alexandria, where the zikr and Koran verses will be intoned for the repose of the soul of the late Sayed Abd El-Khalik El-Saddat, the last of the Wafaieh family.
Alleged Robbery at the Societe Commercials.

Mr. Limbaropoulo, the cashier of the Société Commercials, has been placed under arrest by the local police authorities, as it is considered that the story he gave as to his being attacked by two robbers at the Société Commerciale's offices in Cherif Pacha-street lacks confirmation. He is a native subject.
Thos. Cook & Bon (Egypt) Ltd.

The coupon due May 1 next on the five per cent first mortgage debentures of Thomas Cook and Son (Egypt), Limited, will be paid by the London and Westminster Bank, Temple Bar branch, on and after that date, between the hours of ten and two (Saturdays excepted). The coupons most be left three dear days for examination.
Asile Rudolph.

The committee of the Rudolph Home desire gratefully to tender their heartiest thanks to the ladies of the Rudolph Guild, members of which both in Ramleh and Alexandria have again assisted- by-their gifts of children's clothing to contribute to the benevolent work of this institution. Nearly ICO children have benefited by. their kindness this year. The committee also desire to- acknowledge through our columns the gift of several articles of new clothing sent to the Home by Mr. Horace Bell during the past winter.

div.head: PERSONAL AND Social
div.p: General Sir F. W. F. Forestier-Walker, G.C.M.G., Commander-in-Chief at Gibraltar, who for five years had command of the troops in Egypt, celebrated his 62od birthday last week. Sir Frederick has been Commander-in-Chief at Gibraltar since last (September.
The Rt. Hon. St. John and Mr. Brodrick and Miss Sybil Brodrick have arrived in London from Egypt.

It is stated that Count von Bernstorff, Councilor of Embassy in London, who bee been appointed Consul-General for Egypt, is to be replaced in the British capital by Hen-von Stumm, Councillor of Embassy in Madrid, the latter being succeeded by the Second Secretary of the Embassy in Romp, Baron von der Lancken-Wakenitz, whose place will be taken by Count von Wedel, hitherto Secretary of Legation at the Consulate General in Cairo.

At the Friends' Meeting House, St. Martin'slane, London, the marriage took place last week of Mr. Ernest B. Lichtenberg, consulting engineer to the Bibiani Goldfields, and a son of Mr. C. A. Lichtenberg, proprietor of Messrs. Wills and Co., Ltd., the well-known coaling depots at Port Said, and other stations in the East, and Miss Majorie Holmes, daughter of, Mr. Leonard W. Holmes, London partner of Messrs. J. H. Holmes and Go., electrical engi­neers, Newcastle.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy, Port Said, we notice: Sir John and Lady Fraser, the Misses Fraser, Miss King, Sir A. Fanshawe, the Hon. Littleton, Mr. Kingham, Mr. H. Dubs, Mr. W. Delanoy, Mr. T. A. Adamson, Mr. and Mrs. Garnett, Capt., and Mrs. Flower, Mr. Park, Mr. Biddulph, Miss Biddulph, Mr. Chute, Mr. Highland, M. J. Shanks, Mr. Rodda, Dr. and Mrs. Patterson, Capt. Baines, Dr. A. Bolte, Mr. Telf, Mr. Evans, Mr. Kemp, Mr. Cron.

div.head: Increase of British Garrison.
div.p: 6th Inniskilling Dragoons Ordered to Egypt.
(Gazette's Special Service
London, Thursday

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive granted an audience yesterday morning to M. Gennadis, the Hellenic Consul-General in Cairo, who introduced to his High­ness M. Stoubis, the Hellenic judge in the Mixed Court of Mansourah.

M. Korber, a Geneva architect, has been commissioned by the Khedive to build a summer palace on the western shore of the Bosphorus, at a cost of about half a million. The Khedive, it is stated, intends to reside there daring a portion of every year, making the palace a point of departure for his Euro­pean tours. The Sultan has offered the choice of several sites.

div.head: The Bakers' Strike
div.p: The strike of the bakers' men at Alexandria still continues, the master-bakers refusing to accede to the men's demands of more pay and less work. Many people are laying in stocks of bread for two or three days in anticipation of the supply of the "staff of life" tailing short.

div.head: Lottery Circulars from Egypt.
div.p: The introduction of peony postage between England and Egypt has led to one unlooked- for development in the business of the Alex­andrian post office. It is much cheaper now to Bend lottery circulars from the continent of Europe as freight by steamer to Egypt so as to make use of the cheap postal rates here to despatch them to England. On this subject a correspondent writes to the "Times": "The Postmaster-General has taken steps to prevent circulation through the British Post Office of German and Austro-Hungarian lottery circulars, bat these steps are now being circumvented by the foreign bank agents who issue these circulars posting them in Alex­andria, in Egypt, and thence, by this circuitous journey, the missives reach the addressees without question. Cannot the same watchful protection to British subjects now exercised over the mail bags from Berlin, Hamburg, Vienna, Budapest, etc., be directed to the mail-bags from Egypt?"

div.head: The Drug Evil
div.p: To the Editor of the ''Egyptian Gazette"
Sir, — Yesterday afternoon a voluntary poisoning took place here at Kafr Zayat.

A young fellow Attempted his life by taking a pastille of sublimate. Fortunately thanks to the immediate arrival of a physician on the scene the danger was averted and the fellow is now ont of danger.

When we Afterwards met the doctor he was very indignant, and rightly to, at a new druggist here who takes it upon himself to make the doctor more than it should be safely Allowed him, and at such critical instances more especially.

This gentleman indeed is want of practicing this sort of adulterated business—for the admixture is otherwise of unknown professional appelatiop—indiscriminately to all, the natives of coarse in particular, for he gives out drugs of all kinds at his own pleasure and regardless of doctors' prescriptions ; this case being an example where the doctor is in possession of an emetic he (the druggist) now gave, in a similar manner, and which owing to the timely arrival of the doctor was not given, being inadequate for the sort of poisoning.
We ask what might have happened had those people depended on this drag and had not had sent for a physician 1
After what happened at Cairo last year, we shall leave it for the legal authorities to answer, by their at least endeavouring to put a possible check to this sort of evil before it is again too late.
Kafr Zayat, April 28. C.a F.ir

div.head: The Princes' Case
div.p: Brilliant Defence of "Ismail the Magnificent."

The procès des Princes opened yesterday in torrid weather at the Cairo Mixed Courts before Judge Prunières and MM. Martinoff, Ragheb Bey Bahr, Prampolini, and Youssef Bey Aziz, judges, and Emin Bey Ghali, Ministre Publique. The court-room, despite the khamseen, was crowded, the Cairo Bar being present in great force, while the Press was also largely represented. Mr. Edward Dicey, C.B., was among the audience, while at the (bar were Maitres Carton de Wiart, Manusardi, and Wassif.

From 9.40 a.m. to 11.40 a.m. Me. Villa pleaded on behalf of the Princes. His speech was pronounced by all who could appreciate Italian to be a masterpiece of pleading in clear and well-chosen language.

After thanking the tribunal for permitting him to plead in Italian, and making a very complimentary reference to the Mixed Courts, Me. Villa opened with an eloquent defense of Ismail Pacha. The famous Viceroy had dreamt of a revival of the Egyptian Empire; he bad detached his country. from the Porte, and, determining to make the best use of the soil of the Nile Valley, had acquired great estates which he hoped to render productive and one day divide among his people. He was no monopolist -he had dreamt of malting Egypt free, rich, and progressive, and the Egypt of today owed its being to the Khedive's dreams. He had been accused of squandering Ids realm's revenues. True, his family and his country had incurred heavy debts, an A to-day the Egyptian Debt amounts to three mil­liards of francs. Yet take Egypt's assets to­day—the Suez Canal, irrigation works cover­ing the Delta, towns rich, prosperous, and civilized. Can such be the results of a spend­thrift policy 1 He seized land—yes ; but as a guarantee against debt. So tar from waste, his acquisitions were a form of national savings bank, for the automatic payment of the country's debt Moreover, many of these properties came to him from his own forbears ; he held them in his private capacity - a special Daira was appointed for their management The Convention of July 12, 1877, proved that the late Khedive was the sole owner of these lands and the State and its creditors alike re­garded him as such. In that contract all was arranged for mortgages in favour of the credi­tors, the rate of interest and the amortisation of the debt. But this contract was a private act, not an agreement into which the State entered. Ismail Pacha did not and could not cede these properties. The Government might plead that some of them had been acquired from the funds of the State—what then 1 The purchaser of land with another's money makes a fair purchase and becomes debtor to the lender : Ismail was therefore debtor to the 3tate bat in those days Ismail was the State. The separation between the State and the Ruler of Egypt was of later date and the Khedive at the time of the acquisition of these properties was an absolute despot whose powers were only limited by the moral law. A tyrant be was not—his very errors were caused by his largeness of view.

At the close of his speech load applause broke out, only to be suppressed, and Judge Prunikres, after complimenting Me. Villa for the compli­ments he had paid the Bench declared that though he had been obliged to repress out­ward manifestations of admiration among the audience, he shared their feelings to the full.

Me. Pietri opened his speech at 11.40 a.m. with a tribute to Ismail Pacha followed by a eulogy of Me. Villa's fine speech. He then gave the reasons on account of which the Government could not entertain the Princes' claims. He summed up the history of the Daira Sanieh and then opened his criticism of the defense. The properties of the Daira Sanieh had bran declared State property; the interpretation of the famous Article 40 of the Law of Liquidation was the base of the whole discussion and was favourable to the Govern­ment. Article 40 read literally shows that the Princes' claim has no serious foundation, the conditions under which the Daira Sanieh debt was contracted must also be borne in mind. Then came the two Commissions, whose reports he quoted at length. Their evidence showed that the Daira Sanieh lands were 3tate lands—not the private property of the ruler. He gave the necessary details of Is­mail Pacha's cession of the Daira lands to the State and declared, basing his arguments on the memorial drawn up in 1886 in the same of the ex-Khedive and the Princes, that the Khedive had ceded these lands absolutely. Commenting on the views ex pressed by various legal authorities and at­tached to this memorial, he pointed out that the Government advocates at that data were all of his opinion.

At 1 p.m. the Court rose. Proceedings were resumed at 4.30 p.m., when Me. Pietri resumed his pleading. In spite of the want of clearness of the ex Khedive's memorial it was dear enough that Ismail Pacha's and the Princes' demand for an allowance from the Civil List was made in consideration of the cession of their lands. The allow­ance wrote off the debt for the cession. The arrangement of 1888 was next dismissed. Prom this arrangement it resulted the Princes' new claims were inadmissible. They had re­nounced their claims in 1888, they could not

sew them In 1906. The letters exchanged tween the Government and the Princes were quoted. No question as to any ultimate sur­plus resulting from their exploitation arose in them. Ismail and the Princes had in so many words renounced all farther claims; the claims made to-day were therefore "non-receivable?-*- inadmissible for their remuneration was effec­tive and explicit. Me. Pietri then examined Article 40 of the Law of Liquidation and pointed out that the explanations thereof given counsel for the claimants were based OH a strained interpretation of its. wording. The other articles were explained one by one. Each was intelligible and logical if the Government's interpretation of Article 40 was correct, bat not otherwise. Logic and law combined to support his claim. The most important point was that the Daira Sanieh Debt had become a State Debt as soon as the Khedive Ismail had ceased to rule Egypt. From that moment the Daira Debt was classed with the Privileged Debt and the Unified Debt.

Finally the counsel for the Government de­clared that the meaning of Article* 40 of the Lew of Liquidation was too dear to be distort­ed. It was an ingenious argument to compare the case to that in which a bankrupt regains the surplus proceeding from the sale of his assets after the satisfaction of his creditors, but why did the Princes and the ex-Khedive renounce their claims?

div.head: The Egyptian Question.
div.p: PROPOSED NEW TRIPLE ALLIANCE.

An old Turkish sayings, which we believe to be borrowed from the Koran, says that "there are more roads than one to Koine." It is on a par with our good old Anglo Saxon truism about 'killing a dog," only more dignified. It is a sort of shibboleth of Pan Islamism, and as such is the motto of our leading Egyptian contemporary "Al Moayed" and its correspon­dents, who have carried this policy to apish of fine art rarely exhibited, in their method of attacking Great Britain's position in Egypt.

The following epistle from its Singapore correspondent, the Yemenite Sayed Serif El Den, is refreshingly characteristic of this mode of offensive stratagem. Sayed El Den is a well-known writer, it appears, and to empha­size his statements "Al Moayed" commits them to a leading article, of which this is an inter­pretation —

"Long ago I had an idea that were an alliance to be formed between Turkey, Ger­many, and Russia against England and her adherents, British influence would be anpram; Egypt restored to Turkey; the balance of power generally adjusted, and public security established on a firm basis. India, also, would obtain complete independence and have restor­ed to it its Imperial Government, which was swallowed op by the British Lion. I did not, however, think then about making my ideas public, knowing the great obstacles that stood in the way of such an alliance, and it was not until I saw similar ideas published in different papers that I was encouraged to forward you this statement, with a few remarks thereon. The chief obstacle to such an alliance is one of finance. Turkey is obviously poor ; Russia has an empty Treasury ; while as regards Germany, supposing she were to impoverish her subject?, who would hold oat to her a helping hand 1 Such an alliance would win fresh laurels for the German Emperor. By its realization France would come between the hammer and anvil, but this would not be the first time that she would be deceived and harmed by the sons of the Thames, as proves. But if France awakens before farther difficulties arise, and avails herself of an opportunity to cancel the Anglo-French Agreement of April 8, she would show fresh evidence of her desire to act as protector of the Orient, despite the artful Power which fold her the skin of a wolf on a mountain. By so doing Prance could avoid a crisis and remove the stain of the guilt she has committed, securing benefits, and finally realizing these dreams."

We congratulate "Al Moayed" on the keen political foresight of its Arabian representative. His poetic allegory about the skin of a wolf on a mountain is possibly a household word in the land from which oar contemporary's cor­respondent hails. It is unhappily not translatable into English idioms. iEiop, by whom we swear on this side of the Equator, employs the skin of a lion to hide the figure of an case.

div.head: The Frontier Dispute
div.p: (Prom our Correspondent).
Suez, Wednesday.
The erniser Nour el Bahr arrived at Suez this forenoon from Akaba, and will return again next Saturday morning, with stores for H.M.S. Diana.
It is stated that the Turkish troops at Akaba are making fortifications along the shore, and that farther reinforcements are expected from Constantinople overland.
The heat is intense in the Gn'f, and many Turkish soldiers are dying daily trom hard­ships.

The Khedive proceeded yesterday morning to Abde9n Palace and gave audience to the Ministers. Shortly afterwards Ghazi Moktar Pacha saw his Highness and a conversation on the frontier question took place. Thi Prime Minister and the Minister of Foreign Affairs were present. The meeting was pot arranged beforehand, and it is presumed that it was due to the arrival of fresh informa­tion from Constantinople.

div.head: Quarantine in Turkey
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states arrivals in Turkish ports from Alexandria and Port Skid have to undergo 24 hoars' observa­tion, disinfection, and "deratisation."

div.head: H.M.S. Monmouth
div.p: Suez, Wednesday.
H.M.S. Monmontb came out of the Caned this afternoon. She is bound to the China station in place of H.M S. Donegal, which returned home owing to her stranding in the Gulf of Suez.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. Syrian Prince, from Antwerp and London, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Wednesday, and is due at Alex­andria on Sunday morning next.
The S.S. Spartan Prince arrived this morn­ing and will proceed to Manchester.
The M. M. steamer Senegal arrived at Marseilles yesterday morning from Alexandria.
V. . -vs-
Conversation with a more or less enlightened native! in Upper Egypt.
Question: Is your religion also under a Ministry like the P.W.D.
Answer : No, but wo are given to understand that it shortly will be, to unable the authorities to appoint another Adviser.

div.head: Egyptian's Experiences in London.
div.p: AN EXTRAORDINARY CAREER.
At the Newington Sessions, London, last week, William Zobin, 31, described as an Egyptian subject, pleaded guilty to baring committed three burglaries at Wandsworth.

The prisoner told a remarkable story. His father was a German, and his mother a Jewess, and he was born in Cairo. He seemed to have been a guide to visitors in Cairo, and was an accomplished linguist, boasting that he was able to speak seven languages. Two years ago he went to London with a sum of £3,5f0. Within six months he had squandered his money in pleasure, being especially fond of motoring. Becoming stranded, he took to bur­glary, end displayed great conning. His me­thod was to hide in the garden of a house daring the evening and then patiently wait until the inmates had gone to bed. Haring obtained admission, he leisurely collected every article of value and waited until about six a.m., when he would leave the house by the front door "as if he was going to work. In April last year he was captured and sentenced at the Clerkenwell Sessions to nine months' hard labour. He was liberated on Jan. 6, and soon recommended his operations. Between Jan. 12 and March 15 there were fourteen oases of burglary within a radius of half a mile in Balham, and it was evident that they were all the work of one man. Twenty police officers were pot on special duty, and about six o'clock on the morning on March 15 Police-constable Crowhurst saw prisoner leave 12, Ravensley-road, by the front door. He knew the occupier, Mr. Parrey, and blcoming suspicions, the constable* stopped prisoner, who remarked that he was going to work. Crowhurst searched him, and found that his pockets were filled with silver spoons and other property, value about £50 in all Pri­soner refused to give any amount of himself, but his address was discovered at Myrtle- street, Whitechapel, where property connecting him with five other burglaries was found. There was no doubt prisoner could give some va­luable information as to the disposal of pro­perty, bat he declined to divulge anything. At his lodging was a letter from his brother at Cairo, stating that the "Prince of Texas" had been inquiring as to his whereabouts.
Prisoner said he stole with the object of getting enough money to return to Egypt.
Mr. McConnell : You are a regular foreign burglar, and mast go to servitude for three years.
The police in the case were commended.

div.head: Englishwoman's Suicide
div.p: The coroner's inquest into the circumstances attending the death of Miss Jessie Brown resumed its sittings at the British Consulate at Alexandria this morning. The evidence showed that the deceased attempted to buy corrosive sublimate at a chemist's in the town. This chemist stated that he refused to serve her, but no evidence was forthcoming as to where she obtained it. The court held that she committed suicide while temporarily insane.

div.head: The Aboukir Company
div.p: ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

The annual meeting of the shareholders of the Aboukir Company, Ltd., was held at Palmerston House, Bisphosphate, London, last week, Mr. Gerald A. Sheppard (Chairman) presiding. The chairman referred to the loss sustained <by the company in the death of the late chairman, Mr. Samuel G. Sheppard, who was one of the original founders of the com­pany. Other changes in the board had occurred during the year, Mr. Leonard B. Sohle- singer, who had been a director from within a few months of formation, having resigned, and Mr. S. Gurney Sheppard, Mr. Arthur Balance, and Mr. Leonard Polly having joined the board. Mr. Lang Anderson, the general mana­ger in Egypt, had also been appointed a director. An important feature of the year's working, Mr. Sheppard said, was that they had no arrears to deal with in presenting their accounts, the last having been paid in January last. Another point was the wonderful in­crease in the prior of land, which had risen to £76 per feddan, for instalment transactions. This latter fact led to an important considera­tion : what was to be the policy of the com­pany in the future ? They bad noticed that land they had sold not very long ago had changed hands after a short interval, at a con­siderable increase in price, and they thought they ought to have something of this. The board quite realised they might be asked to sell, but it would take a large sum in oash to indnoe them to do so. They had not been without offers of considerable magnitude, but he thought for the present the shareholders might expect to remain land-holders in Egypt, The company had sold about 11,000 foddans, and he should not like to estimate the value of the remaining land, but they would have observed that for some years it had Keen continually increasing in value. The late chairman put the value at £30 per feddan, but he thought it was a great deal higher to-day. By the end of this year about 7,000 feddans would be in course of reclamation, and next year they hoped to canalize a farther 2.000, and in 1908 the remaining 2,000. The new syphon they had placed under the Mah- moudieh Canal had proved very satisfactory, and daring the heavy rains last year, when there was a fall of 6 inches in eight days, the water ran off quite easily. Eb moved that the directors' report and balance sheet be adopted, and this was unanimously agreed to.

Mr. Lang Anderson paid a tribute to the excellent work done for the company by the late Mr. Samuel Sheppard, and mentioned that for over 15 years he wrote to him,Mr. An­derson, a weekly letter dealing with Aboukir. But for the excellent assistance he gave in its earlier days the company would not have existed up till the present Referring to the new chairman, he remarked that he found it a great aid to nave at the head of the one who was so conversant as Me. Gerald Sheppard was with every detail of the work they had in hand. Mneh had been said about the boom of land in Egypt Thanks to the good work of the Irrigation Department, and the satisfactory condition of the country generally, there was much more security than hitherto. Formerly a man had one third of his land under cotton ; cotton was then worth 23) piasters, per canter, and the natives did not like to buy land for mere than 10 year's purchase. To-day half of this land was under cotton, cotton was now worth 350 piasters percent and land was bought on 15 years' purchase. He consider­ed the present price of cotton was not high, but was steady. As to the price of land, the circum­stances perfectly warranted the increased valuations. There was an important factor in the situation—the population. Egypt was the most densely populated country in the world, there being 11,000 people to the square mile. It was absolutely an agricultural country, and the people mast depend upon agriculture. Then, too, there was the intense desire of the people to possess land. They did not go in for company investment: they did not understand it. Land was the only investment they oared to take np. The present price of land was absolutely solid. A large amount of land could be bought now to yield 6 % or 7 %, with a chance of improvement. The chairman did not care to pat a value on the land the company still held, but ho, Mr. Anderson, had not the slightest hesitation in saying that it was worth half a million. (Hear, hear): They had something like £150,009 in unmetered instalments on land sold, which made the estate very large indeed. They were getting on rapidly with the property, and when the whole of it was canalised they would work up the rental to a substantial figure.

Resolutions declaring dividends of 7 % on the Ordinary and Deferred shares were carried. Mr. Gerald Sheppard was re-elected a director of the company, and a vote of thanks to the chairman and directors concluded a cordial meeting.

div.head: La Land Bank of Egypt
div.p: BXERCICB 190.V190S

La Land Bank of Egypt a été constituée le 10 janvier 1905 aa oapital de £500,000, re présente par 95,000 aotiona de £ 5 et 5,000 parts de fondateurs da môme prix. Les 95,000 aotioDi ont été émises aveo une prime de 10 sbelliogs aa profit da fonds de réserve. Le 4 novembre dernior le oapital a été porté à an million de Livres sterling par la création de 100,000 actions nouvelles de £5, émises avec ane prime de £8 au profit da fonds deié Berve. Les nouvelles actions jouissent d'an intérêt de 5 % sur le oapital nominal depuis les dates des versements jusqu'au 31 mars 1906. Pour le prochain exercice elles sont assi­milables aux anciennes actions.

Au moment de sa création, la Land Bank of Egypt a obtena le droit d'émettre des obliga­tions au porteur, pour un montant égal à cirq fois le oapital versé. Toutefois, cette préroga­tive a été soumise à diverses conditions cons­tituant on surcroît de garantie pour les por­teurs d'obligations : 1° le montant des obliga­tions ne peut en auoun cas excéder le montant des engagements des emprunteurs hypothé­caires ; 3° un relevé des prêts hypothécaires effectués, dressé par les greffiers conservateurs des hypothèques près les Tribunaux Mixtes, doit être annexé au bilan soumis annuellement à l'assemblée géaérale des actionnaire», ainsi qu'un état dressé par la banque indiquant le montant des sommes reoonvrées sur les dits prêts. Cela, joint à la garantie du capital social et des réserves, constitue une eé :urité excep­tionnelle pour les obligataires.

60,000 obligations 3 1/2 %, de fr. 5C0 oha- oune, jouissanoe 1er juillet 1905 et rembour­sables à fr. 505 en 75 années ont été placées par le Conseil d'Administration. La valeur nominale de oes obligations est de L E964.375; en déduisant le montant des primes à amortir, soit LE 118.134, 957/1000. on obtient un solde au bilan de LE 846.289. 063/1000.

Le total des réserves, qui s'élève à L.B. 248,579 910/1000, se décompose de la ma­nière snivante : LE 46,312 1/2 montant de la prime versée par les souscripteurs des 95000 actions anciennes ; LE 195,000 montant de la prime sur les 109,000 actions nouvelles, et LE 2,267 440/.000, montant de la réserve statutaire.

Four les prêts hypothécaires, la société fait une enquête approfondie sur la moralité et lx solvabilité des emprunteurs ; de plos, tous ses prêts sont garantis par des hypothèques en premier rang qui représentent au minimum le double de la valeur des prêts; par surcroît de garantie, la banque ne oonssnt des prêts qae sur des domaines ruraux en pleine exploitation ou sur des immeubles de rapport des villes du Caire et d'Alexandrie.

Le montant aes prêts amortissables par an­nuités s'élève pour l'exercioe h L E 1,964,037 299/1000; dédaotion faite des amortissements résultant des annuités éohues et des rembour­sements anticipés, oe total se réduit à LE. 1,858.833 896/1000.

Les orédite en oompte courant garantis par hypothèques représentent une somme de L.E 162,450. Dédaotion faite des remboursements anticipés, des versements effectués par les cré dités et des crédits non utilisés, ce oompte se solde au 81 mars 1906 par LE 133,341 662/1000.

La banque a escompté pour L.E 54.638 099/1000 de créanoes en se faisant subroger aux privilèges attachés aux dits prêts et eu les faisant en outre garantir par les cédants qui sont des personnes d'une solvabilité incontesta­ble. Dédaotion faite du paiement des annuités, oe compte se solde au 31 mars par L.E 46,333 172/1000.
Le solde des oapitaux dûs au 31 Mars 1S06 et garantis par hypothèques est donc de LE 2,033,608 130/1C00.

Voioi la situation des autres comptes an 31 mars 1906 : recouvrements des annuités LE. 3,269 411/1000 en voie de recouvrement; dépôts pour régularisation de prêts L.E 10,225 894/1000 ; oaisse et oomptes créditeurs en banques LE 161,845 371/100); avanoes à court terme L E 48,517 219/10 00 échues ou à échoir; débiteurs divers LE 353 107/1C00 représentant des montants en suspens qii seront réglés é oonrt délai ; créditeurs divers LE 11,860 731/1000,même remarque que pour débiteurs divers.

La Banque a acheté dans le oourant de l'année éoôulée un immeuble «imposé de deux propriétés oontigué*, situées à Alexandrie au ooin des rnes Tonssoun Pacha et Constantinople No. 17, d'ane superficie de 6852. 2/00 pics carrés, dans l'intention d'y construire un édifico dont une partie devait être destinée aux Bu­reaux de la Banque et le reste divisé en appar­tements de rapport. Depuis, ayant trouvé preneur à on prix avantageux pour une partie du terrain non nécessaire à la construction projetée, il a été oédé pics 2000 environ de la surfera précédemment mentionnée. Le susdit immeuble figure au Bilan pour LE. 25.K4.394/ ou Fr. 650.794,41 représentant le ooftt d'achat, les frais de transfert et de oourtage et les hono raires de l'architecte.

I* somme figurant au compte Caisse de Prévoyance poar le personnel s'élève à LE. 479, 875/ Fr. 122.'8,69 provenant de la prime gracieusement abandonnée par le Syndicat de garantie des actions. A partir du proohain exeroioe oette Caisse sera alimentée: 1° par une retenue de 6% sur les appointements du Pe - sonnel ; V une somme égale à prélever sur les bénéfices de la Banque ; 3' les intérêts aflérents à oes fonds.
Le oompte Profits et pertes s'établit comme suit:

Les produits résultant des intérêts des prêts hypotbéoaires. des oomptes courants, des avan- oes à court terme, de3 intérêts de retard, dei indemnités de remboursements anticipés, etc. s'élèvent à LE. 106.663, 013/ ; les frais divers à LE 80.083. 866/; les bénéfices acquis à l'exercice s'élèrent dono à LE. 55,580, 647.

De oe montant il faut d'abord prélever l'in­térêt statutaire de 5% revenant aux 95.000 actions anciennes ordinaires, soit LE 23,156. 250/ et un intérêt de 5% sur le oapital nominal des 100,000 notions nouvelles à partir des épo­ques des versements, soit L.E 6,760.

Sur le reste, LE 25,674 397/, il y a lieu de prélever en oompte Provision sur recouvrements en oonrs LE. 8,000 etsurlesolde, LE. 22,674, 397/ : 10 % poar constituer le fonds de réserve statutaire ; 10 % pour rémunérer le Conseil d'Administration.
Le solde da LE 18,139 517/ est à répartir comme suit : 70 % aux porteur.) des actions anciennes, 30 % aux parts de fondation.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

The scarcity of loanable funds in all the lead­ing financial centres is having its due effect on our market, and here we are in the third week of April with the Bank rate at 3 $ % and the open market rate very little behind. New York and Paris are the points which are giving ns most concern, for gold has been going to both places during the past week. As regards the former, it is hoped that the demand for gold is nearly, if not alto­gether, satisfied, but the cable rate stands weak at about 4.85, and it is very uncertain what the fall effect of the terrible disaster at San Francisco will be. So far the effect has been not only to dispel the expectation of a rise in the exchange, hut to farther de­press it The Paris market is, however, the more potent factor at present in the creation of disturbance here, and with the prepara­tions for the Russian loan, stiff money rates, and the exchange down at 25.09 $, it cannot be wondered at; whilst, of course, any gold on offer here naturally flows to the French I centre.

Under these circumstances rates could not do otherwise than stiffen, and to-day call loans fetch 3$ to 3$%, and loans for the week 3 £ % with a firm tendency, and discount rates, fol­lowing in the wake of money, have also harden­ed, bills commanding 3§% for all maturities up to three months.

The question of a rise in the Bank rate is mooted in some quarters, but such an event is not at all likely, and, indeed, bills for forward delivery, say in 10 days, can be done at the spot rate. It is quite likely that the present rates will even be maintained for the remainder , of the month. We should see some money re- : taming from the provinces during the next few days, and when the Russian loan has been placed, no doubt some French money will find its way to this market, bat then we shall be faced with the usual end of month require­ments, so we cannot look for much ease until the beginning of May.

The Bank of England returns published yes­terday tend to bear out the above-mentioned view. There is a reduction of £880,000 owing to the recent gold withdrawals, and the market balances are reduced 1 million as shown in the decrease in Other Deposits. Since the re­turn, too, further sums in gold have been with­drawn from the Bank's coffers for shipment. The Stock Market*.

It is the unexpected that always happens. The terrible catastrophes in Italy and San Francisco, the shaking of the very foundations of the earth, have naturally had a most serious effect upon the bourses all over the world, and ( notwithstanding the fine position which the trade of the world is now reaching, such di­sasters as these are calculated to put the look backwards. What the ultimate effect of the destruction, on such a huge scale, of life and property is likely to be in this particular case it is impossible to forecast. Fortunately the American nation, with the £50,000,000 which they will receive from the British insurance offices, is in a position to replace these losses to a large extent, but confidence will not be easily restored, and it is not likely that San Francisco will be rebuilt in anything like its former proportions, at any rate, not for many years to come.

No doubt a large part of the compensation and relief funds will have to go in rebuilding either there or elsewhere, and the immediate influence on trade ought not to be prejudicial, out the effect upon many of the railways, banks, and other institutions cannot but be serious.
A holiday tone has prevailed in the markets here throughout the week, and there has been little dealing other than of a professional character.
Gilt-edged Stocks.
The weakness of these stocks has been typical of the general dullness, and Consols have been quoted lower. They close to-night at 90$ for cash and 90$ for the account.
Foreign Bonds.

Heavy selling of Russian Fours has taken place in Paris in order to release money for the Dew loan, and the price of these has fallen to 81$. The new loan, which is being quotidian l$ premium, has affected the foreign Govern­ment market generally, which has been idle. Japanese Fours close at 9§ as against 92 last week.
Home Railways.
Notwithstanding the fine Easter and the magnificent traffic returns which are sure to follow, there is no heart to buy these securities for a rise. The market is as lifeless as ever.

The traffic receipts for the quarter to date show big increases for most of the impale, the North Eastern having a gain of £150, 00, the North Western following this up with £144,000 and the Midland with £110,000.
American*.

The fearful disaster in California has natu­rally had a very serious effect upon the American market, and yesterday prices all-round showed considerable decreases. The weakness continues to-day, farther reductions being marked. The dosing quotations in the leading shares are as follows : Aitchison, 92ft; Baltimore, 113$ ; Canadian Pacifics, 178$ ; Chicago and Milwaukee, 178; Erie, 44ft; Illinois Central, 178 ; Louisville, 152 ; New York Central, 146$; Pennsylvania shares, 71$ ; Philadelphia and Reading, 65}; Southern Pacifies, 66$; Union Pacific's, If6}; Steel Common, 43$$. Do. Pref 111$.
Egyptians.

There has been little business passing in the Egyptian market since the holidays, and prices have inclined to ease off slightly. Delta Land and Investment have been the most active market, and have again been up to 6ft, a second time falling back to 4f, at which price they dose. Land and General have been down to ft premium, but buyers have come forward, and they leave off firm at $ premium. National Bank of Egypt dose down at 27, and Agriculturals at 10$.

Daira Ordinary at 18, and the Deferred at 105 are also easier. Daira Sugar are a dull market at about 4$. Agricultural Bank 3$ % bonds are better at 93$. Union Fonciere and Bank of Abyssinia at 6$ and $ premium res­pectively are quite unchanged. Delta Prefer­ence Bearer distinctly easier at about 13. Egyptian Estates are scarce and firm at 2 ft. Corporation of Western Egypt are $ premium. New Egyptian show no change at 1 $$. Egyp­tian Markets have been enquired for at 1$, but there have been no dealings. Bank of Roumana are lifeless at 9$-10$.
Mining.

Curiously enough the South African market seems to have been under the depression caused by the upheaval in San Francisco to an abhor mal degree, and probably the reason is that there is so little inclination to deal in this market that any unfavourable outside occurrence becomes "bear" influence. This in itself is an indication of the unsatisfactory state of things ruling in this Beotion. Rand Mines leave off lower to-night at 6$ and East Rands at 5ft.

In the Egyptian mining market a lethargic spirit has been prevalent, and there have been no movements worthy of note. Egyptian Options advanced to 1 $f as a result of the publication of the circular confirming previous advices re developments in the company's pro­perty. These certainly point to an excep­tionally rich concern. The shares close rather down to-night at 1$|. Nile Valley have been quiet, and leave off without change at 6s. 6d.

div.head: The Cotton Market
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report, d
Liverpool, April 19.

Business in Egyptian Cotton this week has been interfered with by the holidays, but a fair b business has been done on the few days the market has been open, and quotations are 7 raised for Good and Fine, and all others are I . $d per lb higher. In Fatures a good business 1 has been done, and the following are the latest p . quotations : -
Apl. 10.2d July 10.0 Oct. 9.22
June 101 Sept. 9.49 Dec. 8 45

; American Futures. The Market this week only resumed business on Tuesday after the q, ' Easter Holidays. The tone was steady but ^ has since eased off and to-day's dosing prices are generally 8 @ 9 points below those of 80 last week. There is no special feature, the business passing is limited, and there is an entire absence of speculation. There is still ^ some anxiety as to the question of the demand for an increase in wages, of which notice has been given by the operatives. The weather conditions latterly have been more favourable of the crop, and there has been some liquidation of American interests in this market.
